work scheduling autonomy 1: The research position allows me to make my own decisions about how to schedule my work.
work scheduling autonomy 2: The research position allows me to decide on the order in which things are done.
work scheduling autonomy 3: The research position allows me to plan how I do my work.
decision making autonomy 1: The research position gives me a chance to use my personal initiative or judgment in carrying out the work.
decision making autonomy 2: The research position allows me to make a lot of decisions on my own.
decision making autonomy 3: The research position provides me with significant autonomy in making decisions.
work methods autonomy 1: The research position allows me to make decisions about what methods I use to complete my work.
work methods autonomy 2: The research position gives me considerable opportunity for independence and freedom in how I do the work.
work methods autonomy 3: The research position allows me to decide on my own how to go about doing my work.
task variety 1: The research position involves a great deal of task variety.
task variety 2: The research position involves doing a number of different things.
task variety 3: The research position requires the performance of a wide range of tasks.
task variety 4: The research position involves performing a variety of tasks.
task significance 1: The results of my work are likely to significantly affect the lives of other people.
task significance 2: The research position itself is very significant and important in the broader scheme of things.
task significance 3: The research position has a large impact on people outside the organization.
task significance 4: The work performed in the research position has a significant impact on people outside my research group.
task identity 1: The research position involves completing a piece of work that has an obvious beginning and end.
task identity 2: The research position is arranged so that I can do an entire piece of work from beginning to end.
task identity 3: The research position provides me the chance to completely finish the pieces of work I begin.
task identity 4: The research position allows me to complete work I start.
feedback from job 1: The work activities themselves provide direct and clear information about the effectiveness (e.g., quality and quantity) of my performance.
feedback from job 2: The research position itself provides feedback on my performance.
feedback from job 3: The research position itself provides me with information about my performance.
job complexity 1: The research position requires that I only do one task or activity at a time.
job complexity 2: The tasks of the research position are simple and uncomplicated.
job complexity 3: The research position comprises relatively uncomplicated tasks.
job complexity 4: The research position involves performing relatively simple tasks.
information processing 1: The research position requires me to monitor a great deal of information.
information processing 2: The research position requires that I engage in a large amount of thinking.
information processing 3: The research position requires me to keep track of more than one thing at a time.
information processing 4: The research position requires me to analyze a lot of information.
problem solving 1: The research position involves solving problems that have no obvious correct answer.
problem solving 2: The research position requires me to be creative.
problem solving 3: The research position often involves dealing with problems that I have not met before.
problem solving 4: The research position requires unique ideas or solutions to problems.
skill variety 1: The research position requires a variety of skills.
skill variety 2: The research position requires me to utilize a variety of different skills in order to complete the work.
skill variety 3: The research position requires me to use a number of complex or high-level skills.
skill variety 4: The research position requires the use of a number of skills.
specialization 1: The research position is highly specialized in terms of purpose, tasks, or activities.
specialization 2: The tools, procedures, materials, and so forth used in this research position are highly specialized in terms of purpose.
specialization 3: The research position requires very specialized knowledge and skills.
specialization 4: The research position requires a depth of knowledge and expertise.
social support 1: I have the opportunity to develop close friendships in this research position.
social support 2: I have the chance in this research position to get to know other people.
social support 3: I have the opportunity to meet with others in this research position.
social support 4: My group leader is concerned about the welfare of the people in the research group.
social support 5: People I work with take a personal interest in me.
social support 6: People I work with are friendly.
initiated interdependence 1: The research position requires me to accomplish my work before others complete their work.
initiated interdepenence 2: Other jobs depend directly on my job.
initiated interdependence 3: Unless my job gets done, other jobs cannot be completed.
received interdependence 1: My research activities are greatly affected by the work of other people.
received interdependence 2: The research project depends on the work of many different people for its completion.
received interdependence 3: My work cannot be done unless others do their work.
interaction outside research group 1: The research position requires spending a great deal of time with people outside my research group.
interaction outside research group 2: The research position involves interaction with people who are not members of my research group.
interaction outside research group 3: In this research position, I frequently communicate with people who do not work in the same research group as I do.
interaction outside research group 4: The research position involves a great deal of interaction with people outside my research group.
feedback from others 1: I receive a great deal of information from my project leader and peers about my work performance.
feedback from others 2: Other people in the research group, such as group leader and peers, provide information about the effectiveness (e.g., quality and quantity) of my work performance.
feedback from others 3: I receive feedback on my performance from other people in my group (such as my project leader or peers).
faculty/project leader feedback 1: I receive a great deal of information from my group leader about my work performance.
faculty/projecdt leader feedback 2: My group leader provides information about the effectiveness (e.g., quality and quantity) of my work performance.
faculty/project leader feedback 3: I receive feedback on my performance from my group leader.
peer feedback 1: I receive a great deal of information from other students in my group about my work performance.
peer feedback 2: Other students in the research group provide information about the effectiveness (e.g., quality and quantity) of my work performance.
peer feedback 3: I receive feedback on my performance from other students in my group.
ergonomics 1: The seating arrangements in my research space are adequate (e.g., ample opportunities to sit, comfortable chairs, good postural support).
ergonomics 2: The research space allows for all size differences between people in terms of clearance, reach, eye height, legroom, etc.
ergonomics 3: The research position involves excessive reaching.
physical demands 1: The research position requires a great deal of muscular endurance.
physical demands 2: The research position requires a great deal of muscular strength.
physical demands 3: The research position requires a lot of physical effort.
work conditions 1: The research space is free from excessive noise.
work conditions 2: The climate in the research space is comfortable in terms of temperature and humidity.
work conditions 3: The research position has a low risk of accident.
work conditions 4: The research position takes place in an environment free from health hazards (e.g., chemicals, fumes, etc.).
work conditions 5: The research position occurs in a clean environment.
equipment use 1: The research position involves the use of a variety of different equipment.
equipment use 2: The research position involves the use of complex equipment or technology.
equipment use 3: A lot of time was required to learn the equipment used in the research position.

Items: Items distinct between URE and Work Experience

work scheduling autonomy 1: What type of organization do you work in?
work scheduling autonomy 2: Which of degrees did you earn and what year did you earn them in (fill all that apply)
work scheduling autonomy 3: In which year did you work at the position for which you are answering the survey?
decision making autonomy 1: [database should calculate number of years since earning degrees]
decision making autonomy 2: How do you spend your time in this job?

work scheduling autonomy 3: default - current year, ability to change to any reasonable year

work scheduling autonomy 1: I. Characteristics of undergraduate research experience

Think about your current or recent undergraduate research experience during the academic year (not summer!)  This section asks you about your research group, research setting, and the time commitments during your academic-year research experience.
work methods autonomy 2: The time investment and other commitments

work scheduling autonomy 1: What is the primary discipline of your research?
work scheduling autonomy 2: How many undergraduate students, including yourself, are/were in your research group at the time of your participation?
work scheduling autonomy 3: How many people in total were in your research group?
decision making autonomy 1: Who was primarily responsible for mentoring and expert advice related to your research?
decision making autonomy 2: What was the primary setting for your research?
decision making autonomy 3: Approximately how was your research time distributed between settings?
work methods autonomy 1: 7.1. How many hours per week did you work on research-related activities in your most recent research experience?
work methods autonomy 2: 7.2. During the same time period, how many hours per week did you devote to extracurricular activities (such as clubs, volunteering, sports, music or theater, other hobbies)?
work methods autonomy 3: 7.3. During the same time period, how many hours per week did you work in a paid job unrelated to your research (on campus or off campus).
task variety 1: 7.4. During the same time period, how many hours per week did you devote to other commitments or obligations that were not listed above? (e.g. caring for family members, unpaid work in a family business).
task variety 2: 7.5 During the same time period, what was your status in terms of academic courses or units?

decision making autonomy 3: response options: boxes with numeric values for each of the settings below; 3 settings should add up to 100%

decision making autonomy 1: Graduate student, technician, or staff scientist
A faculty member is a person holding an advanced degree such as Ph.D. or Ed.D. and a job at the college or university.
decision making autonomy 2: Laboratory research: activities in a space dedicated to conducting experiments and observations to collect data.

decision making autonomy 1: A postdoctoral researcher is a person holding an advanced degree such as Ph.D. or Ed.D and continuing their training.
decision making autonomy 2: Fieldwork: activities that involve observations and data collection in the natural environment. This includes classroom observations for education research.

decision making autonomy 1: Graduate students, technicians, or staff scientists are people who are invested in the research project and are not holding a doctoral degree.
decision making autonomy 2: Computational work: collecting data using remote instrumentation (e.g. satellite, telescope) or simulation and modeling software; data analysis for the data generated in the lab or in the field.

decision making autonomy 1: Other: a consultant is a person who was not invested in the project, but possesses relevant expertise.
decision making autonomy 2: Collecting data in the lab or in the field with the use of computers contributes towards lab or field research.
